questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his urine has been pink since this morning. During the past 2 days, he has had a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. He also reports having a low-grade fever. He has no pain with urination or changes in urinary frequency. He has had two similar episodes involving a sore throat and pink urine over the past 2 years. His older sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Oral examination shows an erythematous pharynx and enlarged tonsils. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
20,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
8 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
3+


 Protein

1+


 RBC

15–17/hpf with dysmorphic features


 RBC casts

numerous


Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows no abnormalities. A renal biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins
Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Capillary wire looping, which is characterized by diffuse subendothelial glomerular deposits, is a typical light microscopy finding in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN). DPGN is most common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can manifest with gross hematuria, increased serum creatinine concentration, and nephritic sediment following an upper respiratory infection. The patient does have a family history of SLE. However, he does not have any findings of SLE, such as a rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain, nor does he have symptoms of any other systemic disease that would predispose him to develop DPGN, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a renal cortex biopsy specimen (PAS stain; 250x magnification)

Sections of numerous tubules and vessels and three centrally located renal glomeruli (blue outlines) are visible. The latter show a partially increased mesangial cell density (examples indicated by black outlines), thickened capillary loops (due to subepithelial immune complex deposits; examples indicated by blue overlay), extracapillary epithelial proliferation (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (examples indicated by arrowheads).

These findings are characteristic of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, the most common form of lupus nephritis, in which more than half of the glomeruli are affected.

B) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane suggests Alport syndrome, which typically manifests with episodes of gross hematuria that are often precipitated by upper respiratory infections. As the disease progresses, findings may include nephritic sediment on urinalysis and a decrease in kidney function (increased serum creatinine and urea nitrogen concentrations). However, in almost all males with Alport syndrome, hematuria is first detected during infancy, making the diagnosis unlikely in a boy who has not had any episodes until adolescence. In addition, affected individuals often have a personal or family history of sensorineural hearing loss and/or ocular findings (e.g., lenticonus).
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).

These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins in the glomeruli are characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Breaks in the glomerular capillary wall (due to any kind of severe injury) lead to an accumulation of plasma products (e.g., fibrinogen) within the Bowman capsule and result in fibrin formation. RPGN can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), increased serum creatinine and urea nitrogen concentrations, and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. However, renal insufficiency is usually more pronounced at diagnosis, with a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL), decreased urine output, hypertension, and edema.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

D) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy most frequently manifests during the second or third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually during or immediately following an infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities, such as microhematuria. The most likely explanation for these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

The treatment of IgA nephropathy includes monitoring of kidney function and initiation of treatment if the disease progresses (e.g., ACE inhibitors for hypertension and/or proteinuria). Immunosuppressive therapy may be indicated in more severe cases. Even with the appropriate treatment, up to 50% of the patients progress to end-stage renal disease within 20–25 years. This patient's increased serum creatinine concentration is concerning for severe or progressive disease and warrants further evaluation with renal biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

E) INCORRECT:

Effacement of the foot processes is a typical finding on electron microscopy in minimal change disease (MCD). Though MCD typically occurs following a viral infection, such as viral pharyngitis, it manifests with nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome. This patient does not have any features of nephrotic syndrome, such as heavy proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or thromboembolism, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, this disease most often affects children < 6 years of age.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of kidney tissue

The effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).

This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are typically seen on immunofluorescent microscopy of a kidney biopsy sample in patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). PSGN can manifest with gross hematuria following an episode of pharyngitis. However, PSGN usually manifests 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, this diagnosis is most common in young children and older individuals and is uncommon in adolescents. In addition, it does not result in recurrent episodes of hematuria. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical findings of PSGN, such as hypertension and edema.
Image Description:

Immunofluorescence photomicrograph of a renal biopsy specimen (very high magnification)

Subepithelial deposits of C3 are seen distributed within the capillary loops. The deposits are visible as bright green fluorescence in an irregular granular pattern.

This finding is typical of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria that are always associated with pharyngitis. His urinalysis findings are consistent with a glomerular origin of the blood (RBCs with dysmorphic features and RBC casts). This combination suggests Berger disease.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of intermittent dark urine and mild flank pain. She has also had a cough, sore throat, and runny nose for the past 5 days. She has not had dysuria. She takes no medications. She has no known allergies. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination of the back shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



Platelet count
200,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

4.9 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 HCO3-

22 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Urine



 Color

yellow


 Blood

3+


 Protein

1+


 Leukocyte esterase
negative


An ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial renal inflammation occurs in acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), which may result in hematuria and mild proteinuria. AIN is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs (particularly antibiotics or NSAIDs). This patient takes no medications. In addition, AIN is associated with fever, rash, eosinophilia, oliguria, and laboratory evidence of acute kidney injury (e.g., elevated creatinine), none of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal papillary necrosis is caused by coagulative necrosis of the renal medullary pyramids and papillae and manifests with hematuria, flank pain, and proteinuria. However, renal papillary necrosis is typically caused by sickle cell disease, pyelonephritis, NSAIDs, diabetes mellitus, or urinary tract obstruction, none of which are present in this patient. A different cause is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Renal glomerular damage occurs in IgA nephropathy, which is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. IgA nephropathy, in which IgA immune complexes deposit in the mesangium of renal glomeruli, is the most common cause of glomerulonephritis in adults. It manifests with hematuria (isolated or recurrent), flank pain, and mild proteinuria with concurrent or recent (within 1 week) upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. The impaired glomerular filtration barrier allows damaged RBCs to enter the tubules and form RBC casts. It rarely causes frank nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension and edema) or significant acute kidney injury, but the resulting mesangial proliferation can cause progressive kidney disease over several decades in up to half of patients. Signs of glomerular hematuria include dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, and proteinuria; signs of non-glomerular hematuria include red or pink urine and passage of blood clots.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemic tubular injury is a cause of acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which results from impaired blood flow to the kidneys. ATN is most commonly caused by shock, severe sepsis, or heart failure, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, ischemic tubular injury typically results in acute kidney injury, manifesting with oliguria as well as elevated serum creatinine and urea nitrogen, neither of which this patient has. Finally, flank pain and hematuria are usually absent in ATN.

E) INCORRECT:

A calculus in the renal pelvis typically manifests with hematuria and flank pain that can radiate to the groin. However, flank pain due to urolithiasis is usually not associated with proteinuria and is typically very severe, while this patient's pain is mild. Moreover, ultrasound can usually detect stones in the renal calyx with high sensitivity; this patient's ultrasound showed no abnormalities.

F) INCORRECT:

Urothelial neoplasia (e.g., transitional cell carcinoma) is classically associated with painless hematuria as well as a history of smoking, phenacetin, or arsenic exposure. Urothelial cancer is most commonly seen in older patients (60–80 years old) and would be very unusual in a 29-year-old patient. In addition, flank pain and proteinuria are not characteristic of this condition.
questions.hint: Urinalysis will most likely show dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a sore throat, nonproductive cough, and bloody urine for 3 days. He has had 2 similar episodes involving a sore throat and bloody urine over the past year. His sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 8 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows acanthocytes and red blood cell casts. Renal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. A renal biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement
Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy most frequently presents during the second to third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually during or immediately following an infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities such as microhematuria. The most likely explanation for these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit into the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction).

B) INCORRECT:

Capillary wire looping, which is characterized by diffuse subendothelial glomerular deposits, is a typical electron microscopic finding in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. DPGN is most common in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment following an upper respiratory infection, as in this case. Although this patient does have a positive family history of SLE, he does not have any findings of SLE such as a rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain. He also does not have symptoms of any other systemic disease that would predispose him to develop DPGN.

While this patient's presentation is consistent with Berger's disease, which is another common cause of DPGN, this sequela usually presents in older individuals rather than in adolescents.

C) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane suggests Alport syndrome, which typically presents with episodes of gross hematuria that are often precipitated by upper respiratory infections. As the disease progresses, findings may include nephritic sediment on urinalysis and a decrease in kidney function (elevated BUN and serum creatinine). However, in almost all males with Alport syndrome, hematuria is first detected during infancy, making the diagnosis unlikely in a boy who has not had any episodes until adolescence. In addition, affected individuals often have a personal or family history of sensorineural hearing loss and/or ocular findings (e.g., lenticonus).

D) INCORRECT:

Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 complement are typically seen on immunofluorescent microscopy of a kidney biopsy sample in patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. PSGN can present with gross hematuria following an episode of pharyngitis, as described here. However, PSGN usually manifests ∼ 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, this diagnosis is most common in young children and older adults, not adolescents. In addition, multiple episodes of hematuria would be unusual, especially in the absence of other typical findings of PSGN such as hypertension and edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Effacement of the foot processes is a typical finding on electron microscopy in minimal change disease (MCD). While MCD typically occurs following a viral infection, such as viral pharyngitis, it presents with nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome. This patient does not have any features of nephrotic syndrome, such as heavy proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or thromboembolism, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, this disease most often affects children younger than 6 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Crescents of fibrin and plasma proteins in the glomeruli are characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). Breaks in the glomerular capillary wall (due to any kind of severe injury) lead to an accumulation of plasma products (e.g., fibrinogen) within the Bowman's capsule and result in fibrin formation. RPGN may present with gross hematuria, elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis), increased BUN and serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment on urinalysis. However, renal insufficiency is usually more pronounced at diagnosis, with a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL), decreased urine output, hypertension, and edema.

Berger's disease is one of the possible causes of RPGN. Therefore, signs of disease progression (e.g., hypertension, decrease in urine output, or rapid increase in BUN or serum creatinine) always warrants further testing.
questions.hint: This patient presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria associated with pharyngitis. His urinalysis findings are consistent with a glomerular origin of the blood (RBCs with dysmorphic features and RBC casts). This combination suggests Berger disease.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of intermittent bloody urine. He has not had dysuria or abdominal pain. There has been no change in urine output or urinary frequency. He has also had a runny nose, dry cough, and a sore throat for the past 4 days. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. There is flank tenderness to palpation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
11,200/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
10 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL


 Complement C3

111 mg/dL (N = 80–160)


Urine



 Blood
3+


 Protein
2+


 RBC
12/hpf with dysmorphic features


 RBC casts
numerous


Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane disease (Goodpasture syndrome) most commonly affects young adult male individuals and can manifest with nephritic-range proteinuria and hematuria. However, Goodpasture syndrome also affects the pulmonary capillary basement membrane (in most cases; due to autoantibodies against collagen type IV), leading to hemoptysis and dyspnea, none of which is seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) often occurs following a viral infection. However, MCD manifests with nephrotic-range proteinuria and edema, which is not seen here. Finally, MCD most commonly affects children < 6 years of age.

C) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy most commonly manifests during the second or third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, flank pain, low-grade fever, and/or nephritic syndrome, usually during or immediately following (within days) an upper respiratory tract infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities, such as microhematuria. The most likely etiology of these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction). A renal biopsy provides a definitive diagnosis but is usually only indicated if there are signs of severe or progressive disease (e.g., proteinuria > 0.5–1 g/24 h, hypertension, elevated creatinine levels).

D) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can manifest with hypertension and gross hematuria following upper respiratory tract infection. PSGN is more common in children, however, and usually manifests 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, C3 complement levels are low in PSGN, whereas this patient's C3 complement levels are normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Alport syndrome most commonly affects male individuals and manifests with intermittent episodes of gross hematuria. As the disease progresses, findings may include nephritic sediment on urinalysis and a decrease in kidney function (increased serum creatinine and urea nitrogen concentrations). However, in individuals affected by Alport syndrome, hematuria is almost always detected during infancy or childhood. In addition, a personal or family history of sensorineural hearing loss and/or ocular findings (e.g., lenticonus) is characteristic of Alport syndrome, which this patient does not have.

F) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment. However, DPGN most commonly develops in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE); this man has no features of SLE (e.g., rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain). Moreover, DPGN typically manifests with low serum C3 complement levels.
questions.hint: Renal biopsy would show mesangial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with gross hematuria. For the past 3 days, he has been suffering from an upper respiratory infection (URI) with congestion, a cough, and a low-grade fever. Earlier in the day, he developed painless gross hematuria that he describes as brown-colored. During the past year, he has had two similar episodes, also associated with URIs.
On examination, his blood pressure is 146/88 mm Hg, and he has trace pitting edema in his lower extremities. His lung and cardiac examinations are normal.
Urinalysis reveals 3+ blood, 3+ protein, and >100 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), with multiple red-cell casts.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
136
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.9
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
101
97–107


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.7
0.5–1.0


Leukocytes (per mm3)
6200
4500–13,000


Hematocrit (%)
37.0
37.0–49.0


Platelets (per mm3)
350,000
150,000–450,000


Prothrombin time (sec)
11.5
11.0–14.0


Activated partial thromboplastin time (sec)
31
22–35


C3 (mg/dL)
108
86–184


C4 (mg/dL)
22
20–58


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) can develop 5 to 10 days after colitis caused by Escherichia coli O157:H7 infection. Although HUS causes glomerular disease, it is characterized as a thrombotic microangiopathy, not GN. Patients with HUS have altered renal function and proteinuria but not red-cell casts.

B) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative GN can surface during or after an infection but is associated with low complement levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Post-streptococcal GN, a form of postinfectious GN, occurs 1 to 3 weeks after the onset of infection and is associated with low complement levels.

D) CORRECT:

Recurrent gross hematuria concurrent with an upper respiratory infection (synpharyngitic hematuria) is a classic manifestation of immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy. This patient’s urine findings, including red cells with red-cell casts, are consistent with glomerulonephritis (GN).

Complement levels are helpful in distinguishing forms of GN. They are depressed in postinfectious GN, membranoproliferative GN, and lupus nephritis. In contrast, complement levels are normal in IgA nephropathy, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated GN, and antiglomerular basement membrane-associated GN. In many cases, kidney biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide therapy.

Key learning point: In a teenager with recurrent gross hematuria that coincides with an upper respiratory illness, the most likely diagnosis is immunoglobulin A nephropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

ANCA-associated GN can manifest with upper respiratory symptoms related to the systemic vasculitis itself, but the hematuria would persist rather than recur.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-day history of intermittent bloody urine. He has also had a runny nose, dry cough, and a sore throat for the past 4 days. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. There is flank tenderness to palpation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show elevated serum creatinine; C3 complement levels are within normal limits. Urine studies show:


Blood
3+


Protein
2+


RBC
12/hpf with dysmorphic features


RBC casts
numerous


Ultrasonography of the kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane disease (Goodpasture syndrome) most commonly affects young adult male individuals and can manifest with nephritic-range proteinuria and hematuria. However, Goodpasture syndrome also affects the pulmonary capillary basement membrane (in most cases; due to autoantibodies against collagen type IV), leading to hemoptysis and dyspnea, none of which is seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) often occurs following a viral infection. However, MCD manifests with nephrotic-range proteinuria and edema, which is not seen here. Finally, MCD most commonly affects children < 6 years of age.

C) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy most commonly manifests during the second or third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, flank pain, low-grade fever, and/or nephritic syndrome, usually during or immediately following (within days) an upper respiratory tract infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities, such as microhematuria. The most likely etiology of these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction). A renal biopsy provides a definitive diagnosis but is usually only indicated if there are signs of severe or progressive disease (e.g., proteinuria > 0.5–1 g/24 h, hypertension, elevated creatinine levels).

Key learning point: IgA nephropathy typically presents with recurrent hematuria and nephritic syndrome within days of a mucosal infection, with normal complement levels and mesangial IgA immune complex deposition.

D) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can manifest with hypertension and gross hematuria following upper respiratory tract infection. PSGN is more common in children, however, and usually manifests 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, C3 complement levels are low in PSGN, whereas this patient's C3 complement levels are normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment. However, DPGN most commonly develops in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE); this man has no features of SLE (e.g., rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain). Moreover, DPGN typically manifests with low serum C3 complement levels.
questions.hint: Renal biopsy would show mesangial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with painless, gross hematuria that began during a mild upper respiratory tract infection. He is otherwise healthy and has experienced two additional short-lived episodes of bloody urine after similar infections over the past year. Physical examination reveals borderline elevated blood pressure with no rash or edema. Laboratory evaluation shows red blood cell casts in the urine and normal complement levels.

Blood pressure
130/85 mm Hg

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis often presents with low complement levels due to complement activation and consumption. It is associated with chronic infections or systemic diseases and may present with significant proteinuria and mixed nephritic-nephrotic syndrome. The patient's normocomplementemic profile and recurrent hematuria after infections do not match this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema, rather than gross hematuria with red blood cell casts. The absence of significant proteinuria and edema in the patient distinguishes this presentation from minimal change disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents 1 to 3 weeks after streptococcal infection, not concurrently. It is characterized by low complement levels due to complement consumption, and often includes periorbital edema. The patient's concurrent hematuria during infection, recurrent episodes, and normal complement levels do not align with this condition.

D) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy manifests with mesangial deposition of immune complexes containing IgA, often triggered by mucosal immune responses. Upper respiratory tract infections stimulate IgA production, leading to immune complex formation and glomerular deposition. This condition commonly presents in adolescents and young adults with episodic gross hematuria concurrent with respiratory infections. Laboratory findings, such as red blood cell casts, indicate a glomerular source of bleeding. Normal complement levels suggest limited complement consumption. Renal biopsy typically shows mesangial proliferation with dominant IgA deposits on immunofluorescence, highlighting the immune complex-mediated pathophysiology.

Key learning point: IgA nephropathy is characterized by hematuria that occurs concurrently with or shortly after upper respiratory tract infections, distinguishing it from post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which presents weeks after infection.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of brown-colored urine and flank discomfort. He reports these symptoms began soon after developing a sore throat and nasal congestion. He noticed tea-colored urine immediately upon waking two days ago and has experienced mild malaise but no fever or rash. He denies any history of serious illness, hearing difficulties, or a family history of kidney disease. Physical examination reveals mild bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Serum complement levels
Normal
Normal


Creatinine
130 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Urinalysis

RBC casts present, Protein: 1.2 g/day, No significant pyuria
RBC casts: Absent, Protein: < 0.15 g/day, Pyuria: Absent



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, manifests with hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection due to mesangial deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes. This condition typically presents in young adults with gross hematuria and mild acute kidney injury, evidenced by elevated serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and sub-nephrotic range proteinuria, indicating glomerular injury. Normal serum complement levels help differentiate it from other glomerulonephritides. Diagnosis is confirmed by renal biopsy showing predominant IgA deposition in the mesangium.

Key learning point: IgA nephropathy often presents with hematuria and acute kidney injury shortly after an upper respiratory tract infection, distinguishing it from post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which occurs weeks after infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimal change glomerulonephritis is characterized by nephrotic-range proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema, primarily in children. It does not typically present with hematuria or red blood cell casts, which indicate glomerular inflammation.

C) INCORRECT:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is associated with low complement levels due to complement consumption and is often linked to chronic infections. The normal complement levels and acute presentation following a respiratory infection do not align with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Post-infectious glomerulonephritis usually occurs 1 to 3 weeks after an infection, not immediately. It is often associated with low serum complement levels due to complement consumption, unlike the normal complement levels seen here.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of intermittent dark urine and mild flank pain. She also reports a 5-day history of cough, sore throat, and runny nose. She has not experienced dysuria. She does not take any medications and has no known allergies. Her temperature is 37.0°C. Examination of the back reveals no costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
104 g/L (115–155)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
8.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Platelet count, blood
200 × 109/L (130–380)


Sodium (Na), blood
136 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood
4.9 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Chloride (Cl), blood
101 mmol/L (98–107)


Bicarbonate (HCO3), blood
22 mmol/L (21–32)


Urea, blood
6.4 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood
97 μmol/L (49–93)


Color, urine
Yellow


Blood, urine
3+


Protein, urine
1+


Leukocyte esterase, urine
Negative


An ultrasound of the kidneys and bladder is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal papillary necrosis is caused by coagulative necrosis of the renal medullary pyramids and papillae and manifests with hematuria, flank pain, and proteinuria. However, renal papillary necrosis is typically caused by sickle cell disease, pyelonephritis, NSAIDs, diabetes mellitus, or urinary tract obstruction, none of which are present in this patient. A different cause is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic tubular injury is a cause of acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which results from impaired blood flow to the kidneys. ATN is most commonly caused by shock, severe sepsis, or heart failure, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, ischemic tubular injury typically results in acute kidney injury, manifesting with oliguria as well as elevated serum creatinine and urea nitrogen, neither of which this patient has. Finally, flank pain and hematuria are usually absent in ATN.

C) INCORRECT:

A calculus in the renal pelvis typically manifests with hematuria and flank pain that can radiate to the groin. However, flank pain due to urolithiasis is usually not associated with proteinuria and is typically very severe, while this patient's pain is mild. Moreover, ultrasound can usually detect stones in the renal calyx with high sensitivity; this patient's ultrasound showed no abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Interstitial renal inflammation occurs in acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), which may result in hematuria and mild proteinuria. AIN is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs (particularly antibiotics or NSAIDs). This patient takes no medications. In addition, AIN is associated with fever, rash, eosinophilia, oliguria, and laboratory evidence of acute kidney injury (e.g., elevated creatinine), none of which are present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Renal glomerular damage occurs in IgA nephropathy, which is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. IgA nephropathy, in which IgA immune complexes deposit in the mesangium of renal glomeruli, is the most common cause of glomerulonephritis in adults. It manifests with hematuria (isolated or recurrent), flank pain, and mild proteinuria with concurrent or recent (within 1 week) upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. The impaired glomerular filtration barrier allows damaged RBCs to enter the tubules and form RBC casts. It rarely causes frank nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension and edema) or significant acute kidney injury, but the resulting mesangial proliferation can cause progressive kidney disease over several decades in up to half of patients. Signs of glomerular hematuria include dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, and proteinuria; signs of non-glomerular hematuria include red or pink urine and passage of blood clots.

Key learning point: Renal glomerular damage, such as in IgA nephropathy, commonly causes hematuria and mild proteinuria following recent upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries
questions.hint: Urinalysis will most likely show dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of intermittent hematuria. He also reports a runny nose, dry cough, and sore throat for the past 4 days. His temperature is 38.1°C, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. On examination, there is bilateral flank tenderness. Laboratory studies show elevated serum creatinine and normal C3 complement levels. Urine studies reveal the following:


Blood, urine
3+


Protein, urine
2+


RBC, urine
12/hpf with dysmorphic features


RBC casts, urine
Numerous


Ultrasonography of the kidneys is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IgA nephropathy most commonly manifests during the second or third decade of life with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, flank pain, low-grade fever, and/or nephritic syndrome, usually during or immediately following (within days) an upper respiratory tract infection. Between these episodes, patients typically have asymptomatic urinary abnormalities, such as microhematuria. The most likely etiology of these findings is an increased number of defective circulating IgA antibodies, the synthesis of which is triggered by mucosal infections (e.g., pharyngitis). These IgA antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium of the renal glomerulus, leading to glomerulonephritis (type III hypersensitivity reaction). A renal biopsy provides a definitive diagnosis but is usually only indicated if there are signs of severe or progressive disease (e.g., proteinuria > 0.5–1 g/24 h, hypertension, elevated creatinine levels).

Key learning point: IgA nephropathy typically presents with recurrent hematuria and nephritic syndrome within days of a mucosal infection, with normal complement levels and mesangial IgA immune complex deposition.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) can manifest with gross hematuria, elevated serum creatinine, and nephritic sediment. However, DPGN most commonly develops in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE); this man has no features of SLE (e.g., rash, photosensitivity, or joint pain). Moreover, DPGN typically manifests with low serum C3 complement levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can manifest with hypertension and gross hematuria following upper respiratory tract infection. PSGN is more common in children, however, and usually manifests 1–3 weeks after an acute infection. Furthermore, C3 complement levels are low in PSGN, whereas this patient's C3 complement levels are normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Minimal change disease (MCD) often occurs following a viral infection. However, MCD manifests with nephrotic-range proteinuria and edema, which is not seen here. Finally, MCD most commonly affects children < 6 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane disease (Goodpasture syndrome) most commonly affects young adult male individuals and can manifest with nephritic-range proteinuria and hematuria. However, Goodpasture syndrome also affects the pulmonary capillary basement membrane (in most cases; due to autoantibodies against collagen type IV), leading to hemoptysis and dyspnea, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: Renal biopsy would show mesangial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy.
